title: Have there been changes in staff reporting being ill due to work related stress?
analysis_commentary:
Another way work pressures may manifest itself, is in staff becoming ill due to work related stress.

In 2004 and 2005, nationally around 35% of staff reported that they had been ill due to work-related stress. This fell by approximately 7 percentage points to a low point in 2008 and 2009. From 2010, the number of staff reporting stress began to increase again and there was a sharp increase of 8 percentage points in reports of illness between 2011 and 2012, representing a +27% change, and it remained at this level in 2013.

Up until 2011, there were similar levels of reporting between the different trust types, although on average lower numbers of staff from acute trusts report illness due to work-related stress than staff from ambulance and mental health & learning disability trusts. However, from 2012 the number of staff in ambulance trusts reporting illness due to work-related stress continued to grow at a greater rate and the disparity between ambulance trusts and the levels reported nationally or from other trust types is greater than it had been previously; in 2012 the difference from the nationally reported level was +6% and in 2013 this increased to +11%.
data_source: Department of Health, Survey of NHS Staff
